title: Protocol for density gradient neutrophil isolation and flow cytometry-based characterization from human peripheral blood
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
      The following steps describe how to isolate neutrophils from fresh human
      blood.
    
Neutrophil isolation
Timing: 1–1.5 h
      This step describes the isolation of the neutrophils from human blood
      using a double-gradient Percoll separation starting from 10 mL of
      blood.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2] The blood was drawn in 10 mL Sodium
      Heparin vacutainer tubes. Volumes can be adjusted depending on sample
      availability.
    
Note: All reagents should be brought at
      room temperature (20–25°C). All procedures should be performed in a
      biosafety cabinet.
    
        Add 10 mL 75% Percoll into a 50 mL Conical tube using sterile
        serological pipette.
      
        Carefully overlay 10 mL 62% Percoll on top of 75% Percoll using sterile
        serological pipette.
      
        Dilute 10 mL fresh blood 1:1 in 10 mL of serum-free RPMI 1640 without
        antibiotics.
      
        Carefully overlay 20 mL of diluted blood on top of the 62% Percoll using
        a sterile serological pipette in a dropwise manner (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]), thus bringing to a total volume of 40 mL.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2931-Fig1.jpg
              Figure 1. Neutrophils separation from human blood following
              overlay on Percoll gradient and centrifugation
            
              (A) Drawing and pictures of double layer Percoll gradient before
              (left) and after (right) centrifugation.
            
              (B) After Percoll gradient, neutrophils are identified in
              neutrophils layer between the two Percoll layers. (i.) Few
              low-density granulocytes can be found in the layer between serum
              and Percoll (ii.) Granulocytes (neutrophils + eosinophils) can be
              found between the Percoll layers.
            
Note: Volumes can be adjusted depending on
      the amount of blood drawn per donor. We recommend that the amount of
      diluted blood overlaid is not greater than 1.5 times the volume of the
      Percoll gradient. For instance, 15 mL of drawn blood (i.e. 30 mL of RPMI
      1640 diluted blood) can be overlaid on a gradient of 10 mL of 75% Percoll

and 10 mL of 62% Percoll. This protocol can be adapted also to a 15 mL
      conical tube.
    
        Centrifuge the 50 mL conical tubes at 200 × g for 25 min and
        400 × g for 15 min.
      
Note: Perform above step with acceleration
      and deceleration set to zero on the centrifuge.
    
        Carefully remove tubes following centrifugation so not to disrupt the
        gradient. The separation of cells and respective bands are shown in
        Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1].
        
            Use sterile transfer pipettes or micropipettes to first collect
            peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) on top of the 62% Percoll
            layers.
          
            Then use sterile transfer pipettes or micropipettes to collect
            neutrophils positioned between the 75% and 62% Percoll layers and
            transfer the cells to a new 50 mL Conical tube.
          
Note: PBMCs population is positioned on
      top of the 62% Percoll layer. If appropriately performed, red blood cells
      (RBCs) should form a pellet underneath the 75% Percoll layer. Ensure
      careful collection of neutrophils without disrupting the RBC layer.
    
        Add RPMI 1640 to the tube up to a volume of 50 mL. Wash the neutrophils
        by centrifuging at 300 × g for 5 min.
      
        Remove the supernatant completely and resuspend the cell pellet in 1 mL
        of neutrophil buffer.
      
        Add 10 μL of cell suspension to a disposable hemocytometer and count the
        cell number under the microscope.
      
Note: This protocol typically yields an
      average (± SD) of 2.15 × 10+6 (± 0.54 × 10+6)
      neutrophils/mL blood. Neutrophils can be resuspended at 1.0 × 10+6
      cells/mL in neutrophil buffer. In the case that the yield is lesser than
      above mentioned, adjust volume of resuspension in neutrophil buffer
      accordingly, to obtain desired cell concentrations. Cells can be further
      diluted with neutrophil buffer prior to counting.
    
Critical: In order to obtain good

separation, ensure careful overlay of the 62% Percoll on top of the 75%
      Percoll layer, and subsequent careful overlay of diluted blood on top of
      the 62% Percoll layer.
    
Cytospin and staining
Timing: 1–2 h
      This part of the protocol describes the steps involved in cytospin. These
      steps allow us to examine the morphology of the neutrophils after Percoll
      gradient-based isolation.
    
        Place cytospin filter paper on top of the microscope slide (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A). Place the cytofunnel on top of the filter paper, making sure the
        holes are aligned.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2931-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. Step-by-step description of cytospin preparation
            
              (A) Place cytospin filter paper on top of the microscope slide.
            
(B) Place the slide and filter paper in to the cytoclip.
(C) Add 100 uL of cells into the well of the cytoclip set.
              (D, E) Following centrifugation, cells are Giemsa and May Grünwald
              stained. Representative image (scale bar: 25 μm) is shown.
            
        Place the slide, filter paper and cytofunnel into the cytoclip with the
        cardboard filters facing the center of the cytospin (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
      
        Aliquot 1.0–2.0 × 10+5 neutrophils in a volume of 100 μL into
        the well of the cytofunnel and slide set (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
      
        Carefully place the cytoclip into the cytocentrifuge and spin at
        800 × g for 5 min at 20–25°C.
      
Note: Ensure proper balance of the
      cytofunnel slide set on the cytocentrifuge.
    
        Following centrifugation, carefully open the cytoclip set and remove the
        filters from their slides.
      
Note: Ensure minimal physical contact with
      cell smears on the slides. Examine each slide under the microscope to
      ensure cells have attached well to the slide.
    
Air dry the slide at 20–25°C for 20 min.
        Stain the slide with May Grünwald stain solution for 5 min at 20–25°C
        and transfer the slide to 1× PBS for 1.5 min.

Stain the slide with diluted Giemsa stain solution (1:20 with Ultrapure
        H2O) for 20 min at 20–25°C.
      
        Wash the slide under running Ultrapure H2O until clean.
      
        Air dry the stained slide at 20–25°C. Mount the slide by adding 1 drop
        of VectaMount mounting medium to the center of the cells and then put
        the coverslip on top (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
      
        Cells can now be imaged using a light microscope with recommended
        magnifications of 40×/100× magnification, and their morphological
        characteristics can be evaluated (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E).
        Note: Neutrophils stained with May Grünwald stain and Giemsa
        stain appear with light purple/pink cytoplasmic granules with violet
        color of multi-lobed nuclei respectively.
      
Antibody titration
Timing: 1–2 h
      This step describes the titration of antibodies for flow cytometry. These
      steps will enable identification of optimal concentrations of antibodies
      for use in flow cytometry assays.
    
Note: This section of the protocol
      describes steps involved in optimizing the neutrophil-related flow
      cytometry panel and is recommended to be performed beforehand. Titrations
      and dilutions recommended in this protocol are manufacturer specific and
      could potentially vary between different lot numbers.
    
        Add 0.5–1 × 10+6 neutrophils in 100 μL neutrophil buffer per
        well in a 96-well U-bottom plate or per tube in round-bottom polystyrene
        tubes.
      
Note: These titrations are valid for a
      total of 0.5–1 × 10+6 neutrophils per sample.
    
        Centrifuge the plate (with lid on) or tubes at 300 × g for 5 min
        at 4°C.
      
        Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in 100 μL FACS buffer + Fc Block
        (diluted 1:100 in FACS buffer) for 20 min on ice or at 4°C.
      
        Centrifuge the plate at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard
        supernatant and resuspend cells in 100 μL of FACS buffer per well.
      
        Perform staining as follows:
        
Resuspend unstained control in 100 μL FACS buffer per well.

Titrate each antibody by adding 5 μL, 2 μL or 1 μL of the respective
            antibodies to 100 μL FACS buffer per well.
          
            Mix each well by pipetting up and down using a multichannel
            micropipette.
          
        Wrap the plate in foil to protect from light and incubate for 30 min at
        4°C.
      
        Following incubation, centrifuge the plate at 300 × g for 5 min
        at 4°C.
      
        Discard supernatant and resuspend cells with 200 μL FACS buffer as a
        wash step.
      
        Centrifuge the plate at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the
        supernatant and resuspend cells in 200 μL FACS buffer per well. The
        cells are now ready to be acquired by flow cytometry.
      
        Analyze acquired data using flow cytometry data analysis software of
        choice and calculate the Separation Index (SI)3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
        (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2931-Fig3.jpg
              Figure 3. Example of Concatenating antibody titration
            
              Neutrophils were either unstained or stained with 1, 2 or 5 μL
              anti-CD45 Alexa 700 antibody respectively. The optimal
              concentration for this specific antibody is 1 μL based on the
              titration.
            
            Representative flow cytometry plots generated using FlowJo and
            related SI are shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].
          
            Based on the fluorescent signal for each antibody, pick the optimal
            dilution factor as shown in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].

Note: The SI is used as a measure for

evaluating the amount of fluorescence for each titration. The higher the
      SI value, the better the separation between the positive and negative
      populations.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Neutrophil staining for flow cytometry
Timing: 1–2 h
      This step describes the staining of neutrophils with a panel of antibodies
      custom designed to identify different neutrophil subsets.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
      Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) controls are used to identify the background
      signal on omitted fluorophores and gate on the positive populations. These
      steps allow us to confirm the positive staining of the neutrophils.
    
        Add 0.5–1 × 10+6 neutrophils in 100 μL neutrophil buffer per
        well into the appropriate wells of a 96-well U-bottom plate.
      
Centrifuge the plate at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
        Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in 200 μL FACS buffer per well.
      
Centrifuge plate at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
        Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in 100 μL FACS buffer + Fc Block
        (diluted 1:100 in FACS buffer) for 20 min on ice or at 4°C.
      
Centrifuge plate at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
        Perform staining as follows:
        
Resuspend unstained control in 100 μL FACS buffer per well.
            Stain the cells with appropriate volume of antibodies based on the
            titration (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
          
            Prepare FMO controls by staining the cells with all antibodies
            except one (example Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2];
            Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).

Wrap plate in foil to protect from light and incubate for 30 min at 4°C.
      
        Following incubation, centrifuge plate at 300 × g for 5 min at
        4°C. Discard supernatant and wash cells with 200 μL FACS buffer per
        well.
      
Centrifuge plate at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
        Discard supernatant and resuspend cells in 200 μL FACS buffer per well.
      
The cells are ready to be acquired by flow cytometer.
Acquisition on the flow cytometer
Timing: 1–2 h
      This part details the acquisition of stained neutrophils using a flow
      cytometer (steps detailed here are specific to BD Symphony, using FACS
      Diva software). Any flow cytometer with the correct number of
      channels/colors and analysis software can be used to perform the steps in
      this protocol.
    
        Prepare unstained and single-stained controls for every fluorophore that
        is used in the panel to correct for fluorescence spillover and set
        appropriate voltages for each channel.
        
            Add 100 μL FACS buffer per well in a 96-well-U bottom plate or per
            tube in round-bottom polystyrene tubes.
          
            Add one drop of compensation beads to each well containing FACS
            buffer.
            
Note: Vortex the beads for 1 min
              prior to use.
            
            Add 1 μL of the antibody to respective wells except the unstained
            control.
          
        Wrap plate in foil to protect from light and incubate for 30 min at 4°C.
      
        Following incubation, centrifuge plate at 300 × g for 5 min at
        4°C.
      
        Discard supernatant and resuspend beads in 200 μL FACS buffer per well.
      
        Controls and samples (from step 41) are now ready for acquisition.
      
        Run the unstained and single-stained beads to set appropriate
        photomultiplier tubes (PMTs) voltage (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A) and
        compensation matrix (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B), followed by the
        acquisition of samples.
      
Note: For best results, we recommended

acquiring the samples within an hour of staining to avoid confounding
      results due to cell activation/damage or death.
